title: Asghar Farhadi’s Oscars 2017 Speech [Full Transcript] – Asghar Farhadi Wins Academy Award for Best Foreign Language Film
text: Getty Advertisement - Continue Reading Below Asghar Farhadi, the Iranian director who previously announced that he would not be attending this year’s Academy Awards as a protest to Donald Trump’s refugee ban, received his second Oscar on Sunday when The Salesman was named Best Foreign-Language Film. Iranian-American engineer Anousheh Ansari accepted the Oscar on Farhadi’s behalf, reading a speech that criticized the President’s “inhumane law.” Perhaps the biggest round of applause yet #oscars pic.twitter.com/LXRJ2hBewj — Cosmopolitan (@Cosmopolitan) February 27, 2017 Here's a full transcript of the speech: It’s a great honor to be receiving this valuable award for the second time. I would like to thank the members of the Academy, my crew in Iran, my producer Alexandre Mallet-Guy, Cohen media, Amazon, and my fellow nominees in the foreign film category. I’m sorry I’m not with you tonight. My absence is out of respect for the people in my country and those of other six nations whom have been disrespected by the inhumane law that bans entry of immigrants to the U.S. Dividing the world into the “us “ and “our enemies” categories creates fear, a deceitful justification for aggression and war. These wars prevent democracy and human rights in countries which have themselves been victims of aggression. Filmmakers can turn their cameras to capture shared human qualities and break stereotypes of various nationalities and religions. They create empathy between “us” and “others,” an empathy which we need today more than ever. Thank you on behalf of Mr. Farhadi. Advertisement - Continue Reading Below According to The Guardian , Farhadi spoke via a video message from Tehran that was broadcasted to a protest and public screening of The Salesman in London earlier in the evening. “This solidarity is off to a great start. I hope this movement will continue and spread for it has within itself the power to stand up to fascism, be victorious in the face of extremism and say no to oppressive political powers everywhere,” he reportedly told the crowd. Getty Farhadi won his first Oscar in the same category in 2012 for his movie A Separation . Follow Peggy on Twitter .
